page.title: 02GUARDBRIDGE - ITS HISTORY
page.content: The village of Guardbridge is of relatively recent origin, though as a crossing point over the Eden it has been important for hundreds of years. According to the 3rd statistical account it derives its name from 'Gair or Gaur' meaning a triangular piece of land and 'bridge' refers to the bridge built by Archbishop Henry Wardlaw which used to carry traffic. It has 6 arches; but due to heavy traffic is now used by pedestrians. A modern bridge stands beside it, taking traffic from St Andrews to Cupar and Dundee. The surrounding area seems to have been of some importance as a port in the distant past, and cargoes of coal, whisky, ale and potatoes were loaded/unloaded. There is even evidence of a railway pier so that goods by rail could be brought right down to the river.
